Dear Maria Madaj:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Required staff
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12205
Section • (1) An agency shall employ or contract for all the following
Description staff positions:
• (a) Chief administrator
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency currently does not have a chief administrator or
licensee designee.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
Former Associate Director of Licensing was interviewed face-
to-face at the agency on December 16, 2024. She stated she,
along with several others, were terminated late afternoon on
Friday, December 13, 2024. She stated the reason given was due
to her position being eliminated and agency restructuring.
Associate Director of Licensing stated she feels the true reason of
her termination was because she was vocal about her opposition
of not agreeing with an agency memo, she felt was inappropriate
regarding LGBTQ youth and foster parents. She stated the
agency does not currently have a Chief Administrator or Licensee
Designee.
Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 19, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024. She stated there is
currently not a Chief Administrator or Licensee Designee.
Former Licensee Designee was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late in the
day on Friday, December 13, 2024. The agency posted her
position later that night and Director of Child Welfare started on
Wednesday, December 18, 2024. She stated the agency does not
currently have a Chief Administrator of Licensee Designee.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and President were not
interviewed. Both were emailed on two separate occasions,
December 18, 2024, and January 2, 2025, requesting to schedule
2

interviews but neither responded. President eventually responded
on January 13, 2025 but did not schedule an interview.
Analysis The agency is found to be in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews it is determined the agency terminated a number of
staff including the Chief Administrator and Licensee Designee
without any plan to ensure replacements were identified in a
timely manner.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Required staff
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12205
Section • (3) An agency shall report any change of chief
Description administrator by the next business day to the department.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not notify DCWL of change of Chief Administrator
within one business day as required.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
Former Associate Director of Licensing was interviewed face-
to-face at the agency on December 16, 2024. She stated she,
along with several others, including the Chief Administrator and
Licensee Designee were terminated late afternoon on Friday,
December 13, 2024. She stated the agency does not currently
have a Chief Administrator or Licensee Designee and was not
aware of the on-site renewal audit inspection scheduled for
January 16, 2024, so she agreed to be present when DCWL
arrived.
Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 19, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024, and DCWL was not
notified of this termination. She stated there is currently not a
Chief Administrator or Licensee Designee and the agency did not
indicate knowledge of the scheduled renewal audit beginning on
January 16, 2025. She stated she pointed it out to the CEO and
President, and they appeared confused and unaware.
3

Former Licensee Designee was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late in the
day on Friday, December 13, 2024. She stated she does not
believe the agency has anyone identified to become the new Chief
Administrator and Licensee Designee. CEO previously held the
role of IT and compliance and has very limited knowledge of child
welfare. President was previously the CEO a few years ago but
had been relieved of her duties due to poor handling of financial
aspects.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and President were not
interviewed. Both were emailed on two separate occasions,
December 18, 2024, and January 2, 2025, requesting to schedule
interviews but neither responded. President eventually responded
on January 13, 2025 but did not schedule an interview.
Analysis The agency is found to be in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews as well as lack of a response from CEO and President
who are the current leaders in charge, the agency made drastic
staffing changes that included termination of Chief Administrator
and Licensee Designee without a plan in place to ensure they
were replaced timely and DCWL was not notified within one
business day as required. The only notification came from
terminated or former employees, not current employees.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Required staff
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12205
Section • (1) An agency shall employ or contract for all the following
Description staff positions:
• (b) Social service supervisor
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency does not currently have a foster care supervisor to
oversee case requirements.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
4

Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 19, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024. She stated there is
currently one foster care supervisor who has put in her notice to
leave and her last day of employment with the agency is Friday,
December 20, 2024.
At the time of her termination there was 7 workers in the office: 5
foster care and 2 licensing. Former Foster Care (FC) Supervisor
resigned on 12/20/2024 and had one foster care worker assigned
to her. Former Chief Administrator had 2 caseload carrying
workers assigned to her and she had 2 cases assigned to her with
her role being foster care worker and Former Licensee Designee
was the assigned FC Supervisor on the 2 cases she had. During
the termination call with the CEO and President, there was never
any discussion or questions regarding anything she was working
on, assignments or case related information. She stated she is
very concerned about the youth on her caseload and other youth
the agency had case management responsibility for.
Former Licensee Designee was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late in the
day on Friday, December 13, 2024. There was no discussion
regarding cases open under the license or anything they needed
to know or how to access the systems or anything the office had
coming up. There was a Teams call that lasted a minute or two.
She stated she believes the agency oversaw approximately 45
cases and feels strongly there is not a current foster care
supervisor overseeing and assisting with case management.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and President were not
interviewed. Both were emailed on two separate occasions,
December 18, 2024, and January 2, 2025, requesting to schedule
interviews but neither responded. President eventually responded
on January 13, 2025 but did not schedule an interview.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS file for Youth A:
As of January 3, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor.
No social work contacts have been entered since Former
Chief Administrator entered a contact on December 13,
2024, which was her last day of employment with the
agency.
• MISACWIS file for Youth B:
5

As of January 3, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor.
No case related social work contacts have been entered
since Former Chief Administrator entered a contact on
December 12, 2024. There is another contact that was
entered on December 17, 2024, that appears to be entered
by administrative support staff indicating a document was
mailed.
Analysis The agency is found to be in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews as well as lack of a response from CEO and President
who are the current leaders in charge, the agency made drastic
staffing changes that included termination of Chief Administrator
and Licensee Designee, who were caseload carrying staff and
supervisor, without a plan in place to ensure all case management
responsibilities were accounted for including required case
assignments.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section • (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
Description child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency terminated staff and did not ensure service plans were
submitted timely.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 19, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024. At the time of her
termination, she was the assigned foster care worker for Youth A
and Youth B. She stated CEO and President did not inquire about
any of the cases she supervised or any cases she was the
6

assigned foster care worker for. She stated there are case
activities she had planned on completing, including a service plan,
but was terminated before she could complete those.
She stated CEO was previously the agency’s IT and compliance
staff. President was previously the CEO but had been terminated
as a result of terrible financial decisions. President hasn’t
completed foster care work in many years and Director of Child
Welfare relied heavily on Former Chief Administrator and Former
Licensee Designee when she was with the agency previously.
Former Chief Administrator expressed deep concern regarding
lack of oversight on the agency’s cases as remaining staff have
very limited knowledge and no one expressed any concern with
ensuring youth were safe and case management activities were
completed as required moving forward.
Former Licensee Designee was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late in the
day on Friday, December 13, 2024. There was no discussion
regarding cases open under the license or anything they needed
to know, how to access the systems or anything the office had
coming up. There was a Teams call that lasted a minute or two.
She stated she was the assigned FC Supervisor for 2 cases
Former Chief Administrator was assigned to.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and President were not
interviewed. Both were emailed on two separate occasions,
December 18, 2024, and January 2, 2025, requesting to schedule
interviews but neither responded. President eventually responded
on January 13, 2025 but did not schedule an interview.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS file for Youth A:
As of January 3, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor.
Updated Service Plan (USP) due December 4, 2024. USP
submitted on December 4, 2024, and recalled on December
10, 2024, by Former Chief Administrator. As of January 3,
2025, Former Chief Administrator and Former Licensee
Designee are both assigned and USP shows “in progress”.
• MISACWIS file for Youth B:
As of January 3, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor.
7

Updated Service Plan (USP) due December 29, 2024. As of
January 3, 2025, this has not been submitted for approval
and is overdue.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as two of two reviewed
service plans were late. Based on completed interviews and
review of Youth A and Youth B’s MISACWIS case file the agency
terminated staff and did not ensure service plans were completed
timely as required.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
Description child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency terminated staff and did not ensure required face-to-face
contacts were completed with youth.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 19, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024. At the time of her
termination, she was the assigned foster care worker for Youth A
and Youth B. She stated CEO and President did not inquire about
any of the cases she supervised or any cases she was the
assigned foster care worker. She stated there are case activities
she had planned on completing, including face-to-face contacts,
but was terminated before she could complete those. She clarified
she made face-to-face contact with Youth B prior to her
termination however did not have a chance to enter the social
work contact in MISACWIS. She was scheduled to make face-to-
face contact with Youth A the following week. Former Chief
Administrator expressed significant concern regarding the
8

wellbeing of the youth on her caseload as well as the other youth
the agency held case management responsibility for.
Former Licensee Designee was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late in the
day on Friday, December 13, 2024. There was no discussion
regarding cases open under the license or anything they needed
to know or how to access the systems or anything the office had
coming up. There was a Teams call that lasted a minute or two.
She stated she was the assigned FC Supervisor for 2 cases
Former Chief Administrator was assigned to. She believes the
agency had case management of approximately 45 cases.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and President were not
interviewed. Both were emailed on two separate occasions,
December 18, 2024, and January 2, 2025, requesting to schedule
interviews but neither responded. President eventually responded
on January 13, 2025, but did not schedule an interview.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS file for Youth A:
As of January 14, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor. On
January 21, 2025, the agency entered a social work contact
indicating face-to-face contact had been made on
December 20, 2024.
• MISACWIS file for Youth B:
As of January 14, 2025, Former Chief Administrator is listed
as the assigned foster care worker and Former Licensee
Designee is listed as the assigned FC Supervisor. On
January 24, 2025, the agency entered a social work contact
indicating face-to-face contact had been made on
December 30, 2024.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as required face-to-face
contacts were made but not entered until well beyond the
timeframe that is required for social work contact entry.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
